div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,144] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, MARCH 10, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are intended to leave Port Baid on or about the following dates:
Port-Said to London Via Brindisi
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails. Combined steamer and sleeping care fair from Port-Said to london via Brindisi or via Marseiles.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Suez about March 10
R.M.S "Orotava" will leave Suez about March 24.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Ormus" will leave Port Said about March 18
R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said about March 27th
N.B.- Homward steamers are sometimes before shels advertised daies,
Passengers landed and embarked at Ismailia, Quearantine Regulations permitting, free of all expenses.
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,966 tons, leaves about March 16.
S.S. Chershore 5,708 tons, leaves about March 30.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about March 6.
S.S. Shropshire 5,220 tons leaves about March 20.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Fitted with Refridgerators, Electric Light, Electric fans, and all recent improvements.
Experienced Stweardesse and Surgeons carried - Agents in Cairo, Messre Thod, Cook & Son.
For all particuars apply to W. Stapledon & Son, Port-Said & Port-Tawfik (Suez)
Note. – The outward Bibby willhenceforth leave suex one day later than before.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: CAPITAL: L. 2,500,000. RESERVE (ENVIRON) : L. 700,000.
Gouverneur: Sir ELWIN PALMER, K.C.B., K.C.M.G.

Siège Social au Caire, Succursale à Alexandria, Agence à Assiout, Assuoan, Benha, Beni-Suef, Chibin el Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Khartoum, Kéneh, Mansourah. Minieh, Port-Said, Suakin, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, Mouski (Caire) et Londres (4 et 5, King William Street).

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

Advances on Merchandise and Securities in current account and for fixed periods. Purchase and sale of stocks and Shares on the London and Continental exchanges, letters of credit issued, valuables reoeived in safe custody. Drafts, cheques and telegraphic transfers issued on the principal towns of the world. Foreign exchange purchased, bills discounted, bills, invoices, annuities and dividends collected and every description of banking business transacted. 18-4-906

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. 28-26

The Hotel is beautifully fitted up and is in the most central part of Cairo. Terms for pension fare at the rate of ten shillings a day. Special terms for officers of Army of Occupation. 24,882-31-10-5

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

To Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa Bay, Durban, about July 4 and August 3.

15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.

div.head: Vienna.
Hotel Bristol. -- I, Kartner-Ring.
div.p: The fashionable residence of the elite of European and American Society, situated in the most central and convenient part of the City. Private Suites of apartments, including drawing, bed, and bathroom. Concert during the Five o'clock Tea and during Dinner.
American Bar, Central Heating, Original Otis Lift, Rooms from 5 Kroen upwards

div.head: Ghezireh Palace Hotel.
div.p: on the bank of the Nile. Formally the palace of late Khedive Ismall. Transformed into a luxurious hotel.
Renouned for its afternoon --- on the West Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellent Trigane Orchestre, Motor Car running to Shepheard's Hotel and vice versa.

div.head: Pagnon's Hotels Luxor
div.p: Luxor Hotel- This old established hotel, accomadating 130 guests is situated amid beautiful gardens with entrance on the river. Resident doctor and Anglican Chaplain, Billiard Rooms, Bar, Electric Lights, and all the conveniences of a first-class European Hote, Tennis Court.
Karnak Hotel- Under same management. Beautifully situated on river. Nice gardens. Guests taken on pension. Moderate terms. Excusions arranged to Thebes, Karnak, etc.

div.head: Grand Continental.
div.p: Open all the year. Unrivaled position in centre of Cairo, opposite Khodival Opera House and Eabekiah Gardens Magnificient Verandah. French Restaurant and Grill-room. Bars and Billiard Saloons open to non-residents. Suppers after the theatre.
George Nungovich Hotels. 24847.3.31.905

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: London St. Ermin's Hotel
div.p: St. James Park. S.W.
A magnificent Hotel of 600 Rooms in a very quiet position in the most accessible part of London, near the shopping centres and theatres, within five minutes of Oberling Cross and Victoria Stations.
Single Bedrooms from 5s. to 9s.
Double Bedrooms from 9s. to 15s.
Inclusive of Attendance and Bath.
Suites of Rooms and Private Bathrooms and Proportionate Terms. Breakfast 2s. to 8s. Luncheon 8s.! Dinner --s.
Telegrams: "Erminites, London" W. Ehrentraut, Manager

div.head: "Al HAYAT " Helouan
div.p: First Class Health Resort
Unrivalled Position on the Mokattam Hills
96 Metres above the level of the Nile, surrounded by desert.
All Rooms full south with sheltered Verandahs
Public Sitting Rooms in seperate pavillions. Communicating by class corridors
Electric Light- Steam Heating - Lift.
Bathing, Air and Diet Cures. Resident Medial Director. All kinds of Sports. Own Tables. Omnibus meets all trains.
Illustrated Prospectus sent free on application

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was warm and summerlike, though in the evening the wind freshened somewhat. During the night it was almost a calm at times and ther was a smooth sea. The day opens fine with a light breee from the S.E. Barometer steady.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
FRIDAY, March 10, 1905.

div.head: The Battle of Mukden
div.p: The great fight that has now been raging for some days around Mukden will, to all appearances, be hereafter considered one of the decisive battles of the world’s history; and the great military catastrophe in Manchuria may well be decisive not merely of the war but of the future of Russian autocracy. While the Government is paralysed by the Terror at home the news from General Kuropatkin’s army is ominous. There is no longer doubt that Oyama’s true strategical objective has at last been attained, and that the Japanese are in the rear of Kuropatkin and have out to the north the railway on which the existence of the Russian armies depend. Now, unless the Japanese are driven off, which is a most unlikely contingency, Russia will be brought face to face with a tragedy, beside which all that Russia has as yet suffered of disaster and humiliation would be as nothing.

It is worth while pausing to consider what the consequence must necessarily be. it must be admitted that in the present case it will be staggering. Not only will the present regime be thrown overboard, and, possibly, even a wholly different form of government imposed. It is not only that the traditional policy of Russia for many generations will, as a matter of necessity, be abandoned, and a wholly different set of activities and developments pursued in its place. Were these all, there might be found more than one parallel for the situation, something to suggest the future of this enormous people. But the real change lies deeper that (TOP the evolution of 9 new dynasty, or

form of government, or national object is nothing less than the decontiuenl of an entire people. The face of Russ the past been set wholly towards the There was some justification for these vast majority of her people were neither anxious for European methods of gave they were content to accept the patriarchal tyranny of the auto divinely ordained necessity in a inanely different from that in which those of Afghanistan acquiesce in the ai of their Amir. We do not propose into the question whether a citing nature would or would not prove date advantage or secure any suits libration of the lot of the commotion of Russia. Only we invite those this unexpectedly sudden evolution tonal independence is a real and only a curious interest to realise t truth which it contains. Pushed to i conclusion, this present rising may the addition of Russia not nowise but actually, to the number of the nations of the old world..

That this—at any rate what ‘this is by no means the .wish of the existing meat of Russia, will not, we iinagtui puled, but we are inclined to think should come at all, it will come in the have suggested, and that by the barrier which the Grand Dukes raL afternoon between the people and there has come first paralysis in the of the present war, and only alter tin remedy a reformation of every patron of the existing regime.

div.head: Constantin Nicolaou
div.p: This evening a concert is to by Mr. Constantin Nicolaou at the Khedivial Hotel. Mr. Nicolaou ranks a celebrated artists who have paid this a visit this year. When quite a given signs of a highly artistic disposition eudowed with a most powerful and supple voice he set upon an artist which developed to the high degree has made of Mr. Nicolaou one of the known singers in Europe. Mr. Nicolaou his education in Paris under the and severe training of M. Masson braced professor Strongly Recommend master he made critical audience in reuse immediately after him :… … your début and successful concert was a most happy even t to me” this “happy event: the one of the most severe critics soon proved to be an accomplished M. Nicolaou at a musical afternoon spacous rooms of the Paris met Tito Ricordi who most warmly him to the “Scala of Milan. It was a leap, but the Mr. Nicolaou stood the test of success both a great singer and actor, that he was once engaged “San Carlo” Naples, and at the Royal” Rom Where he sang in the singer Lohengrin, Valkyrie, Tank et Leandre, Gioconda, Puritani, Barbier de Seville, Mignon, Guille Hugenots, Faust, Falstaff, Rig. This list shows Mr. Nicolaou’s and the marvelous range of a voice could equally suit Verdi, Meyer, and Wagner. To this he adds his knowledge and perfect execution of music, of which he gave such beautiful even in Russian, where he was by the whole press as the rival of the Sialapin. Mr. Nicolaou has been declared King Charles of Roumania, before he sang.

div.head: KUROPATKIN’s danger.
div.p: RAILWAY LINE CUT.
JAPS ADVANCING ON HUN-HO
TokIO, March 9.
The Japanese have cut the railway north of Mukden. (Reuter. /
London. March 9.

The consummate strategy of the Japanese, . .\k;uplified in the operations round Mukden, is universally acknowledged. ‘It is believed •Li* tin* Japanese, profiting by the mistake -i.idea'i hia«' yang, ’ Irnvp concentrated abundant forces along the line «-f retreat, in order to bring about an overwhelming defeat.
Experts draw attention to the fact that the whereat units of Kawawiira’s army, consisting of sixdivisions, is absolutely unknown. (It.)
Tukio, March 9. The Japanese have cut the railway to the north of Mukden. (Havas.)
London, March 9. The telegrams from Oyaiua and Kuropatkin indicate that fierce fighting is proceeding T -rth-Wost of Mukden. (Reuter.)
Toxio, March 9.

'Several Russian counter attacks at Yenshih- and Likuatipu, west of Mukden, have been repuled with heavy loss, The Japanese have occupied Siaochitun, five miles north-west, and Santaitsu, five miles north, of Mukden. (R.)
London, March 10.
Reuter’s Agency learns from Mukden on the sih inst. that on the southern front the Japanese are fast advancing on the Hun-Ho, where the Russians expect to make a stand,
the issue depends on the operations northward along the railway. (Reuter.)

div.head: SITUATION IN RUSSIA.
div.p: St. PETERSBURG, March 10.
Strong forces have been sent to deal with the peasant risings in the provinces of Orel and Tchernigoff, where bauds of men, thousands strong, are looting and burning the estates.
(Reuter.)

div.head: NORTH SEA OUTRAGE
div.p: INDEMNITY FOR FISHERMEN PAID.
. London, March 9.
Count Benckerdorfi has handed to Lord Lansdowne £65,000 as an indemnity for the Hull fishermen. (Reuter.

div.head: FRENCH BUDGET.
div.p: Paris, March 9. The Chamber of Deputies has passed the Budget. (Haras.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Pigeon Shooting will commence at Gabbari on Sunday next at 2.30p.m.
The Brindisi Mail will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 8.30 a.m. on Sunday.
Asile Rudolph.—M. Moiae Aboaf has sub scribed £1 to the funds of the home.
Cairo Rifle Meeting.—The date of the Cairo Hi tie Meeting has been fixed for the 29ill, SOlb^and 31st inst.
Rara Avis. It may interest those of our readers who are amateur ornithologists to know that a couple of woodcock were recently shot near the Delta Barrage.
Papyrus Find.—Our Tahta Correspondent writes that an important find of papyrus has been ljiade among the ruins ot Kom-Eshgar, in the Tahta district. The papyrus has been suit to tlie Moudirich.

Smoring Concert.— We may remiud our icaiiers ot the concert to be given at Alonterra- to* Hail to-morrow evening, by Mr. Soott- Leshe, assisted by several local amateurs. This wm be Mr. Scott Leslie's farewell appearance m Alexandria.

Suez Canal.—Un the 6th ami 7th inst., 20 vesoeis • passed through the Canal, 12 ol which were British, 2 Gorman, 3 Austrian, 2 Freuch, 1 Danish. The receipts lor the two days were lrs. 520,825.04, making the total trom the 1st inst. lrs. 2,170,507.35.

Rabies.—A iiamplnot has recently been published in Trench by M. Teoouile, municipal 'vet, on rabies ami the precautions to be taken against it. The Municipality is plucing this wur* giatuitously at tliu disposal of the public, auu applications may be made for tree copies at Bcuuier s Bookstall, Client Pasha* stieet.

Ghezireii Palace Hotel.—We regret that thiougu a typogiapbical error in our report ol llie Guezireh laucy-dress ball yesterday, Mr. Kay appeared as Mrs. Kay in the descnp*' tiou ot that gentleman s striking tcmiuiue uttire. The “get-up ’ was so good, we believe, that' Mr. Kay was actually asked tor a dance under* the belie! that he was a member ot tiie weaker sex.

Union. ArtistkiUE Fran^aisk.—Tho coin* miitee of the society is . now computed us loilows :—A. Nicolas, president ; li. V. Tnoiu and De Lagurcnne, vice-presidents; Justin i'auj, commissaire de surveillance; Jacques Jautlret, secretary ; Ant. Kubeo, treasuier ; Andre, Lumbroso, 1*. Livi, Robert Mors, Kibcrt, and U. Bargigii, members, in sued hands the society cannot but continue to progress. _____

Novelli at Alexandria.—The audience at iheZizima TheaUe last night was by no means so large as on Wednesday, but Noveih was in splendid toim, and as Trumuoni in the “Rape ut the fannies” showed nis great comic powers. Among tne other niemoers ol me company Sig. Piamouti and Sign*. Giaumui weie the most remarkable. The audience called for a monologue at the close ot the play, but Novelti was too lired ‘to grant the request.

Franco-Italian Ball.—It was unfortunate that this ball ciasbed with that given at Ghe- ziieb Palace un Tuesuay. None the less, a large number ot people were present and the takings were decidedly good. The Marquis de dorogua and M. Bousquet represented the Freuch and Italian Diplomatic Agents. The first prize was given to the pretty children ol M. Morpurgo, the well-known advocate, who symbolised France and Italy, the second to a very charming “Marianne.”

Cairo of To day. — Messrs. A. .and C. Black have just issued the fourth edition ol ibis very bandy little guide to Cairo and the Nile. The book, while not of course enabling the tourist to dispense with bis Baedeker or Murray, forms au excellent substitute for the more bulky guides while on tour, being so woll-arranged that reference is easy in every way. We notice, however, that the author, Mr. Keyuolds-Ball, B.A., has failed to mention, in bis chapter on the regeneration of Egypt, the very important matter of the Anglo French Agreement recently concluded. In oilier respects the book appears to be well up to date, and it is published at tho moderate price of half-a-crown.

“The Pirates of Penzance.—The next pe* formauce of The Pirates <\f Penzqnc<?, to tak«* place at the Khediviul Opera House, Cairo, ou tho 18th inst, will be in aid of the Anglo-American Hospital and of the British Benevolent Fund, and will be under the patronage of Lord Cromer and the Hon. J. W. Kiddle, Consul-General for tho United States of America.''* Everyone is concerned in the prosperity of the hospital, which supplies a want felt by all classes of the community, no less than by the English and American visitors to this country. The last IKjrformauce of the Pirates of Penzance was moreover, of such excellence as to render those who were prevented from witnessing it very desirous of availing themselves of this second opportunity. The caste is iden tical with that of the Royal performance, and the representation will be exactly tin* >atne in every way. A full bouse is therefore expected, and early application should be made for seats to Captain Tucker, R.E., Turf Club, Cairo. The box office will be open un the 11th March. The prices will be as follows : — Baignoires, P.T. 300 ; 1st tier, P.T. 200 ; 2nd tier, P.T. 100 ; stalls, P.T. 40 and 20.

div.head: Russians in the Red Sea
"Massilia" Meets Torpedo- Boats.
div.p: (From our Correspondf.nt).
Suez, Thursday.

The Anchor liner “Massilia,” which arrived at Suez this forenoon, reports that at 2 o'clock this morning she passed seven torpedo-boats cruising about near Ras Garib. One of them came alongside tho steamer, and then followed at a distance for some time. Owing to the darkness the “Masailia” conic! not distinguish the nationality of the warships, which are no doubt Russian.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR GARRISON.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Port Said, Thursday.

The Nfirth German Lloyd 8.S. “Zieten,” which arrived at Port Said early this morning from Yokohama, brought 119 Russian soldiers and 66 Government officials and clerks from Port Arthur. They leave to-day for Odessa by the Russian steamer.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive spent yesterday on his estates
at Mariout.

div.head: THE STRANDING OF THE “CAIRO.”
div.p: The commission of enquiry at midday to day proceeded to the spot where the S.S. “Cairo” lies stranded, and was conducting investigations as we went to press.
The crow of the vessel left yesterday for Italy by the Flurio-Kubattiuo S.S. “Singapore” en route tor Genoa. Only six remained here, including Captain de Marchi, in connection with the inquiry.

Signor Novelli and his company have changed their methods of legal attack, and intend suing the captain of the “Cairo” personally, the Fiorio-Kubattino Steam Navigation Company, and the Administration of the Port ot Alexandria. The case will be heard on Monday next at the Mixed Courts before the tribunal des liters.” Maitre Guidotti will represent the plaiutiils, who demand the nomination of our or of three experts to determine who is responsible for the accident, and to ascertain especially whether the alleged carelessness to the Ports and Lighthouses Administration contributed materially to the damage done to the vessel.
Many otters have been made to the company to refloat the steamer, but nothing has, of yet, been decided.
'1 tic steamer is not insured.
As to the cargo, most the greater part was insured, it has been taken in charge by the companies affected, who will deal with the question of salvage.

div.head: THE ROYAL BETROTHAL.
div.p: The betrothal of Princess Margaret of Connaught to Prince Gustavus Adolphus has a special interest for historical genealogists. At the present moment the only European throne except the not very glorious or -enviable one of Scrvia and that of Turkey, not occupied by a direct descendant of our own king James 1., is the throne of the Beruadottes. The natural consequence, if all goes well, of the marriage of Princess Margaret to the eldest son of the Crown Prince of Norway and Sweden will be that that throne, too, will m course of time be occupied by a descendant of James I.

div.head: SHEPHEARD’S VENETIAN FETE.
div.p: At 10 o’clock last night, the beautiful garden behind Shcpheard’s Hotel was filled with a large and animated crowd who had been attracted thither by the promise of fireworks and of illuminations on a large scale. The whole of the garden had been hung with multicoloured Chinese lauterus in tasteful design, and there being no moon, the effect produced was extremely picturesque. Electric lights had also been fixed in many of the trees, and the rose-coloured lamps ou the tops ot the highest palms completed a very pretty sight.

The fireworks were greatly appreciated and confetti were thrown with such vigour, and in such quantity, that the paths were in places almost ankle-deep. In spite of its being rather a cold night, the gardens were thronged till a ate hour, while dancing went on in the Moorish central hall till long after midnight A large number of well-known Cairo residents, including many of the officers of the British and Egyptian forces, took part in the festivities, and with them were a great number of tourists, principally American, who all seemed to be enjoying themselves immensely.

Among the diners in the restaurant, we noticed 11.1.H. Prince Adalbert of Prussia, with a party of six, among whom was Dr. Rucker-Jenish, German Consol General. Mrs. Carey also entertained a party of six, and other parties were those of Mr. Rutherford, Mr. Devries, Mr. Hiller, Mr. Moroom, etc.
Others to be seen in tbe restaurant were the Rt. Hon. J. W. Mellor, Baron Vogel von Falkenstein, Lady Bell, Countess Holnstein, and Vicomte de Sapucahi.
The Egyptian Infantry band discoursed a programme of music in one of the comers of the garden, while the dance music was provided by the Tzigane orchestra, whoso playing was much appreciated.

There were many supper parties in the grillroom and the gathering did not disperse till nearly 2 o’clock this morning. Our thanks are due to Mr. Baehler and his able staff for a very enjoyable evening.

div.head: THe NEW LOTTERY LAW.
div.p: TEXT OF DECREE
The following is the text of the new Khe- divial decree concerning lotteries, which was approved by the Council of Ministers last Monday :—

Nons, Kbtfdive d’Egypte, sor la proposition de notre ininistre de l’intlrieur et Favis con forme de notre oonseil des ministres ; vu la deliberation de l’assexnbiee general© de la Oonr d’appel mixta en date dn 31 janvier 1905, prise on conformity du decret du 31 j&nvier 1889; le Conseil Legislatif entendu, d4crtf- tous:
Art. ler.—Nul ne pourra, sans une autori sation prealablo de l’administration :

list.item: Colporter, veudre ou mettre en vente, ou distribuer dans les lieux publics, des billets de

div.p: loterie;

list.item: Paire circuler, en les offr&nt en loterie au public, des animaux morts ou vivants ou tout autre objet quelconque;
Paire connaltre 1 existence d'une loterie ou faefiiter le placement des billets par des annouces, affiches, expositions, ou par tout autre rnoyeu de publicity

div.p: Art. 2.—tfont rdputdea loteries toutes opt^ra tious offerees au*public, sous queique denomination que ce suit, dont le beultioe serait acquis umquement par la vote du sort.

L’aasimiiatiun ne s’etend pas aux valours k lots sp4cialement autons4es, soit par le gou veroeinent cgyptien, soit par le gouvemement otranger dont la legislation serait applicable k Remission; mais la vente au public des chances au tirage des cutes valeura esc comprise dans la proiiihitiou de 1 article ler.
’Art. 3.—Toute ouutravention k l’article ler sera pume d’une amende ne depassant pas
P.T. lou.
En cas d’une seconde coudainnation, le juge pourra, outre l'amende, appUquer la peiue d'einprisounement ne depaosant pas une se* maine.
Les billets et objets ayant servi k la con iraventiou scroiit ooutisquds.
Art. 4.—Le present decret entrera en vi gueur 30 jours apr£s sa publication au Journal
OJJiciel.
Fait au palais d’Abdin, let 7 mars 1905.

div.head: NEW MINING LEASE.
div.p: Mr. Ogilvy Haig has been granted a new mining lease by the Egypuau Government, which is known as Be Loan Centre, Lease Huinayab, ami cousints of a rectangular piece u! land consisting ot one 10-acre mining claims and fiil 2^-acre dip, or underlay claims, con- unuiug altogether ten acres (9,633 led dans) iu oue block. The rent is HE 19.266 mills, per annum, aud the lease extends for 30years from January 1, 1905.

Mr. G. u. Haig has beeu granted 39 other leases, under the same conditions as above, at the following centres : egatte 11, Ceiga 6, Urn Teor7, Misbah 1, Aitvi^ieLNajaad 1, Misa 1, Euoway 3, Aoou uuiai2, W .\Laheina 1, Urn Eeagba 2.

div.head: MARRIAGE OF LIEUT.-COL. KENNA.
div.p: The marriage of Lieutenant-Colonel P. A. Keuua, V.C., D.6.O., 21st Lancers (Empress of India's), wno is of course well-known in Egypt, with Angela Mary, youngest daughter ot tiie late Mr. Hubert Hiboert aud Mrs. Hiobert, ot Beaufort-gardens, was celebrated at the Orator)’, London, ou the 2ud mat. The long aisle and portico were lmed by non-com- mibsioned officers and troopers of the bridegroom s regiment. Colonel Powle supported ms brother officer as best man. The bride was accompanied by her brother, Mr. Washington Hibbert, 2nd King's Own Lancasters, and wore a gown of white satin and chiffon with Court train of satin veiled with sequined uet, and draped with Brussels lace, the gifl of her grandmother, Mrs. Hornyold, aud she held a bouquet ot white orchids. There were ten bridesmaids, two o! whom bore the bride’s tram. They were in frocks ol white chiffon over glac4 silk, with pale blue sashes and blue hats tied with chiffon strings. Each wore ,a moonstone pendant with gold chain, on which were the initials of the wearer in diamonds, and carried a bouquet of daffodils tied with long pale blue nbbon. The Rev. Vincent Hornyold officiated, and tbe other priests were Father Sebastian Bowden, S J., tbe Rev. Odo Laugdale, O.8.B., oousin of the bride, the Rev. F. Knapp, and the Rev. Bernard Vaughan, S,J. Lady Lovat lent her house in Grosvenor-gardens for the reception. Princess Henry of Battenberg's gift to the bridegroom was a silver cream ewer and sugar bowl, and Princess Louise of Schleswig-Holstein sent him enamel aleeve- linkB. The colonel and officers of the 21st Lancers presented him with a silver tray.

div.head: P. & O. COMPANY.
div.p: We are desired to state that the P. & 0. Company’s main line steamers to Marseilles regularly leave Port Said at 5 p.m. every Monday after the arrival of the 11 o’clock morning train from Cairo, and a steam tender awaits the train to convey passengers on board.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The 8.8. “Fabian” arrived at Liverpool yesterday.
The Westoott and Laurance SE “Egyptian” left Malta yesterday evening, coming from Antwerp and London, and it due hero on the 18th inst.

p.note:
OPINIONS ON THE ISSUE.
A financial authority writes :—The promo tion of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, is one of the fairest that 1 know oL The only mistake in the prospectus, to my mind, is the omission to state two points, which, instead of being against; are distinctly in favor of the company. The first is that the directors have taken powers to issue £1,000.000 of debentures. Presumably they would not pay more than 4^ per cent for these and, taking for the sake of argument that they could only make 6^ per cent, on their investments in this country, this would give an extra profit of 4 per cent, on the 500,000 shares capital, quite apart from the profits derived from the investment of the £500,000. The second point that does not appear to be clearly stated in the prospectus is that the ordinary shares not only receive a preferential dividend at 5 per cent but accumulative preferential dividend. They then receive 65 per cent, or two- thirds of the balance, and the directors have full powers to create a general reserve fund before anything can be pai l to tbe deferred shareholders. It /is obvious that the people connected with the company are men of the highest integrity, and that a man, such as Mr. Greville Palmer, who has been director of the Bank of Egypt for 28 years, would not lend his name to any shady adventure.
Another correspondent writes:—
L’lmission des actions de cette sociltl, bien que dljk largement oouverte, n’a pas oepen- dant rencontre la favour des courtiers-remisiero et du moude de la bourse en glnlr&l, qui s'oo- oupe plutdt de speculation que de placement.
11 faut aussi admettre que le momeut a 6te mal choisi pour le Ian cement de l’affaire. Outre la crise monetaire qui s4vit sur notre place, le marche des valours eat faible et manque d'en- train.
Mais les promoteurs n en ont cure. 11s 66 preoccupent peu que la souscription soit converts 33 fois i- Le rfidacteur du prospectus n a pas chauffe le client, contr&irement aux usages suivis jusqu'k ce jour. Ne tenant pas k susciter de l'enthousiasme aux foules,il ne fait miroiter aux yeux du public ni concessions de terraijia^ii dividendes mirobolants. 11 ne fait point de pro- messes. 11 dit simplement, en ce qui conoeme les exploitations ionci&res qu’on estime que les opportunity de s'assurer des terrains qui aug- menteront de valour se pryenleront!
Pour les terrains k butir il k%considere que la Cie retirera de cette source de bon* revenus”.
II dit aussi; “que les trav&ux d irrigation et d’&mllioration des terras seront des entre- prises protitables”.
Cast Ik, il nous semble, parlor sans fanfaron- nade et en homme d'affaires.
La presence, dans le Board, d'hommes re- marquablea, engages dejk dans les affaires egyptiennes et de sp&iaiistes comme MM. Slieppard et Lang Anderson sout une garantie suthsante de capacity et d’honngtetl pour la rdusite de l'&ffaire.
Les critiques dirig&s ici contra cette affaire portent en grande p&rtie de gens fortement engages en bourse, qui craigneut de voir d4pn£- cier les anciennes valeura au profit des nou voltes. Les autres sont des bounders, qui ne oom- prenant pas l’anglais, vout lire les joumaux et r£p£tent k leur tour et k lour mani&re les critiques qui y sout formulae*; c ost ainsi que nous voyous en ville des badauds r^peter oouram- rnent “que le tiers des b4n<$fioes et du.... capital seront engloutis par les parts de fonda- teurs I ”
Il est vrai que les journaux qui ont atta- qut* le • prospectus ont oublid (pour cause) de dire que le tiers des bdulfices allouta aux parts de fondAteurs n'4taitpr4lev4 qu!apr&* avoir pay4 le 5 0/0 aux actionnaires.
N’est-il pas legitime, apr£s avoir distribu4 uu intlrdt r&itonnable k l’argent engagd et dot£ le foods de reserve, de destiner sur le surplus des b4n4fioes one part aux promoteurs de l’&ffaire comme retribution de lours services pr£ty avant et apr&s la formation de la society
Car oette entreprise n’est pas, oomme on le pretend, l’oeuvre d’un matin; mais bien le fruit de pluaieurs anutas dt-tudea, d’observa- tions et de recherches.
N’interosse t-on pas le Directeur d’une ban- que dans sa gestion, l’employl des magasins aux benlfioes de la vente ? Qu’y a-t-il lk d’ex- traordinaire et de malpropre ? Oh est aurtout le danger de perdre son argent I N’est-ce pas lk plutdt on moyen pour en gaguer da vantage.
Quant k la nature de l’affaire il nest memo pas nlce8saire de dire qu’elle a des chances de rdussir. Toutes les society foncieres en Egypte proephreot. Jetons un coup d’ccil rd- trospectif sur les sooidty de ce genre et nous venrons par la cote de lours actions les progry qu’ellea ont reality en peu de temps.
AiiVKi la B4h4ra a vu see actions passer de £ 5 prix nominal k £ 50 et 52, la Daira Sanieh de £ 5 k 27, la Soci6t4 Agricole et Industrielle de fr. 500 (en 1898) k fr. 1100, !&Soci4t4 fon- ci^re de £ 20 k 36, l’Eg. Delta Land de £ 1 k 3 7/8, la Wardan Estate de 5 k 7 3/8,la Nile Land Agrioultural de LR 5 k 7 1/4 et la So- oiM d’Aboukir dont le directeur g4n4ral sera 1’admbistrateur d4l4gu4 en Egypte de l’Egjrp- tian Estate donne le 20 % de dividends.
La sooiltl qui offre aujourd’hoi ses actions suivra le progry et les suoys de ses devan- ci^res. Ajoutons que l'Egypti&n Estates s'est assort k Londree le placement de ua million d’obliga- tions aux meiUeores conditions. Les b4n4fioes qui ryulteront du pl&oement de oette somme en Egypte, iront tout naturellement aux eotiona #

note.p: H. R H. Prince Leopold of Batten berg i expected to return to Cairo from his tri] up the Nile on the 19th inst His Boys Highness will pt&v, as before, at the Ghazireh Paiaoe Hotel We hear that his healtl has greatly improved by the trip.
The Countess of Lovelace left Alexandra yesterday for Italy by the Florio-Rub&ttim S.S. “Singapore.” *
Lieutenant Sir J. Eardley Wilmot arrivec at Port Said this morning by the outwan bound Orient 'liner “Ophir.”

Among the latest arrivals at the popula Cataract Hotel at Assouan are Sir Willian and Lady Dolby, the Marchioness of Donegal Count Malvezzi, General de Negrier, B&rot von Haeften, Prince Lichtenstein, Couni Trauttmansdorff, General and Mrs. von Thu men, General and Mrs. von Herw&cht, Baroi Drasche, and Lady Hope.

Other recent arrivals include Mrs. Mounsej Heygate, Miss M. Mounsey, Dr. Rickett, Cav and Mrn. M&yaini, Mr. Roesti, Mr. Muller, Mr K. Boyle, Mr. and Mrs. Lohse, Mr. aud Mrs Klose, Mr. R Hirsch, Mr. Preudenberg, Mr aud Mrs. R Mallinson, Mr. C. Mallinson, Mr and Mrs. Geo. Kiddoch, Rev. Bridgeixuu: Boughton Leigh, Mrs. Tangye, Mr. P. Acton Adams,Miu Edith Collins, Dr. and Mrs. Sharpe, Mrs. C.j Mrs. A., and the Misses Plamondon, Mr. Hope, Mis. R W. Browne, Miss Jerr&m, Mr. and Mrs. N&ville, Mr. A. Neuhaus, Mr. and Mrs. Wigdor, Mr. and Mrs. Berthold Cohn, Mr. and Mrs. Mansfield Hunter.
M. Cronier, Chairman of the Bpard ol the Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d’Egypte, is leaving for Europe to-morrow by thi Austrian Lloyd steamer with his family.
The well-known French actor and poet, M Pad Plan, is leaving Alexandria this after noon for France by the Messageries Maritime] steamer.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Ex change Hotel, Port Said, are Mr. A.Tissier, Mr and MraPaytou,Mr.W.H.Yarrington,Mr.W.B Jones, Mrs. A. W. Ramsay, Mrs. H. Brooks, Mr. and Mrs. Boning and children, Mr. Kirsh ner, Mr. Amstein, Mr., Mrs., and Miss F H. Moore,Misa V. Moore, Mr. Ch. Vassallo, Mr
J. P. Taylor, Excellenz and Mme von Hew&rth Dr. J. Rickett, Mr. 0. Govieff, Baron de li Huerta, Mrs. and Misa Weaatern, Mr. T Funstall, Mr. M. Savon.

Mrs. Stanford, the wealthy American lady who used to visit Egypt annually, and was very weL known up the Njle, is reported to have beer poisoned by strychnine at Honolulu. It il stated that the poison was contained in « bottle of bicarbonate of soda, which she bought originally at Adelaide, in Australia, and got refilled at San Francisco. The deceased lady, who was eighty years of age, was extremely wealthy, and professed to be infeai of a plot against her life. She fied to Honolqlaq to secure, as she said, greater safety. Her Am* rican relatives authorised a statement, completely rejecting the poison theory, exphnning that Mrs. Stanford had been very ill physic&Uj and mentally, and was a victim to hallucina tions, the strongest being that her life was in danger. She died at her hotel, after returning from a picnic with her attendants.

div.head: ST ANDREW’S CHURCH.
div.p: NOTICE is hereby given that the Annual General Meeting of British Residents to audit the accounts of St Andrew’s Church ad Harbour Mission for the year 1904, and U appoint a Treasurer and Trustees for 1905, will be held at H.B.M.’s Consulate, Alexandria on Saturday, the 18th instant, at 4 p.m. R B. Gould, 25564-1 Consul-General

div.head: Savoy Hotel, Luxor.
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its psition on the Nile bank. Under German Management. Moderate charges. Patronized by officer of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily.
